combined_text:

justification: Project focuses on educational support without direct environmental or energy transition impacts

title: Chinese Government grants 2 container scanners worth 42 million RMB to Ecuador National Customs Service through ETCAs (linked to #88148, #35844, and #88177)
description: On 28 September 2012, the Chinese Government signed Letters of Exchange with the Government of Ecuador for the donation of two mobile container inspection equipment machines, model MT1213LT. Additionally, the Chinese government agreed to send a technical team to help with installation and readjustment of the machines, and transport them to the Port of Guayaquil.   The scanners were to be installed and operate in Guayaquil and Puerto Bolívar, and were to benefit the National Customs Service of Ecuador (SENAE). The scanners were produced by NUCTECH.  The project cost was 42 million RMB, according to the Letters (equivalent to 6,433,200 USD), which would be provided through the Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreements (ETCA) that were signed November 20, 2007; November 24, 2009; and November 17, 2010 (see projects #88148, #35844, and #88177). The exact breakdown of funds between these three grants are unknown, though the ranges are, respectively, between 12 million and 18.55 million RMB; between 3.45 million and 10 million RMB; and between 13.45 million and 20 million RMB.   The handover certificate was signed on 18 March 2013.
staff_comments: Potential ranges of the amounts pulled from each ETCA grant are all calculated by subtracting the maximum amounts available from the other two agreement from 42 million RMB for the lower bound, and using the maximum amount available as the upper bound. For example, the range for the November 24, 2009 ETCA is between 3.45 million RMB and 10 million RMB because, (1) regarding the upper bound, there is no evidence of other sub-projects that it funded, indicating up to the full amount could have gone towards this project and (2) regarding the lower bound, up to 20 million RMB from the November 17, 2010 ETCA + up to 18.55 million RMB available from the November 20, 2007 ETCA (see project #88148, calculated by 20 million - 1.45 million - some unknown additional amount) = 38.55 million RMB. 42 million - 38.55 million = 3.45 million RMB at minimum.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRADE POLICIES AND REGULATIONS

# Title
Chinese Government grants 2 container scanners worth 42 million RMB to Ecuador National Customs Service through ETCAs (linked to #88148, #35844, and #88177)

# Description
On 28 September 2012, the Chinese Government signed Letters of Exchange with the Government of Ecuador for the donation of two mobile container inspection equipment machines, model MT1213LT. Additionally, the Chinese government agreed to send a technical team to help with installation and readjustment of the machines, and transport them to the Port of Guayaquil.   The scanners were to be installed and operate in Guayaquil and Puerto Bolívar, and were to benefit the National Customs Service of Ecuador (SENAE). The scanners were produced by NUCTECH.  The project cost was 42 million RMB, according to the Letters (equivalent to 6,433,200 USD), which would be provided through the Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreements (ETCA) that were signed November 20, 2007; November 24, 2009; and November 17, 2010 (see projects #88148, #35844, and #88177). The exact breakdown of funds between these three grants are unknown, though the ranges are, respectively, between 12 million and 18.55 million RMB; between 3.45 million and 10 million RMB; and between 13.45 million and 20 million RMB.   The handover certificate was signed on 18 March 2013.
justification: Project involves donation of container scanners for customs operations, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Mobile container inspection equipment for customs service, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: China sends 7th military medical team to Ecuador  (Linked to Project ID #85605, #88240, and #89533)
description: In November 2012, China sent a team of four military doctors to Ecuador to provide traditional Chinese medicine diagnosis and treatment to thousands of military and civilian patients. This is the 7th team of its kind to be sent by China. In November 2013, the group was awarded Ecuador's highest military honor for their work.   This team's visit was the result of the International Agreement for Medical, Human and Professional Cooperation between the Ministries of National Defense of Ecuador and China(or "Convenio Internacional de Cooperación Médica, Humana y Profesional entre los ministerios de Defensa Nacional de Ecuador y China"), which was signed in 2009.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China sends 7th military medical team to Ecuador  (Linked to Project ID #85605, #88240, and #89533)

# Description
In November 2012, China sent a team of four military doctors to Ecuador to provide traditional Chinese medicine diagnosis and treatment to thousands of military and civilian patients. This is the 7th team of its kind to be sent by China. In November 2013, the group was awarded Ecuador's highest military honor for their work.   This team's visit was the result of the International Agreement for Medical, Human and Professional Cooperation between the Ministries of National Defense of Ecuador and China(or "Convenio Internacional de Cooperación Médica, Humana y Profesional entre los ministerios de Defensa Nacional de Ecuador y China"), which was signed in 2009.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare services without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Military medical team providing traditional Chinese medicine diagnosis and treatment

title: People's Liberation Army funds 8 million RMB of mobile field hospital grant worth 18 million RMB through Free Military Assistance Agreement (linked to #36001)
description: On May 9, 2012, the Ministries of Defense of Ecuador and China signed a protocol agreement, which agreed to grant a mobile field hospital, consisting of vehicles and other equipment, worth 18 million RMB. The field hospital was to be used in Loja by the Motorized Infantry Brigade, part of Ecuador's Armed Forces (FF.AA). Its was to be used for medical emergencies and rescue operations during natural disasters.  This mobile field hospital was co-financed by the People's Liberation Army (captured in this project, 8 million RMB out of 18 million RMB) and China's Ministry of Defense (captured project #36001, 10 million RMB out of 18 million RMB). Both the Ministry of Defense and the PLA funded the field hospital through a Free Military Assistance Agreement with Ecuador.   The Free Military Assistance Agreement between the PLA and the Armed Forces of Ecuador was signed November 12, 2010, and provided an 8 million RMB grant, which is captured in this project. The entire amount was used for the field hospital project. The Free Military Assistance Agreement between China's Ministry of Defense and Ecuador's Ministry of Defense was signed December 27, 2011, and provided a 10 million RMB grant captured project #36001. The entire amount was used to fund the field hospital project as well.  More specifically, the grant contained one of each of the following vehicles: ambulance, surgery vehicle, clinical laboratory vehicle, x-ray and type B ultrasound vehicle, sterilization/pharmacy/storage vehicle, restaurant vehicle, vehicle for medical oxygen preparation, shower vehicle, water purifying vehicle, and support vehicle. It also included one transition tent; four tents with a bed and equipment for triage, ICU, and care; and spare parts for two years of use.  The handover ceremony took place in Loja on July 19, 2013.
staff_comments: This project is not coded as an umbrella project because the entire amount of the grant went towards this project. This project is coded separately from #36001, which captures the portion of the project funded by the Ministry of Defense. Although the funds went to the same project, because the funding agencies are different and it is known how much was contributed by each agency, the grants are separated out. Although project recipient was the Armed Forces, intent set to 'Development' due to the outlined explicit purpose being medical emergencies and disaster relief.
combined_text:
# Sector

# Title

The field hospital was to be used in Loja by the Motorized Infantry Brigade, part of Ecuador's Armed Forces (FF.AA). Its was to be used for medical emergencies and rescue operations during natural disasters.  This mobile field hospital was co-financed by the People's Liberation Army (captured in this project, 8 million RMB out of 18 million RMB) and China's Ministry of Defense (captured project #36001, 10 million RMB out of 18 million RMB). Both the Ministry of Defense and the PLA funded the field hospital through a Free Military Assistance Agreement with Ecuador.   The Free Military Assistance Agreement between the PLA and the Armed Forces of Ecuador was signed November 12, 2010, and provided an 8 million RMB grant, which is captured in this project. The entire amount was used for the field hospital project. The Free Military Assistance Agreement between China's Ministry of Defense and Ecuador's Ministry of Defense was signed December 27, 2011, and provided a 10 million RMB grant captured project #36001. The entire amount was used to fund the field hospital project as well.  More specifically, the grant contained one of each of the following vehicles: ambulance, surgery vehicle, clinical laboratory vehicle, x-ray and type B ultrasound vehicle, sterilization/pharmacy/storage vehicle, restaurant vehicle, vehicle for medical oxygen preparation, shower vehicle, water purifying vehicle, and support vehicle. It also included one transition tent; four tents with a bed and equipment for triage, ICU, and care; and spare parts for two years of use.  The handover ceremony took place in Loja on July 19, 2013.
justification: Project focuses on disaster preparedness and medical assistance without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Mobile field hospital for medical emergencies and rescue operations during natural disasters, consisting of various medical vehicles and equipment

title: Chinese government cancels 747,900 USD of debt accrued for now-cancelled Quito Education Center Project (linked to #85568 and #88259)
description: On February 1, 2005, the governments of Ecuador and China signed Letters of Exchange committing an unknown amount of funding to the Quito Education Center Project (Proyecto de Centro Educativo de Quito) (captured in project #98658).   However, in Letters of Exchange signed November 14, 2011 and April 13, 2012, at the request of the Government of Ecuador, the project was cancelled. At that point, the preliminary design and detailed project exploration had already taken place. The costs associated with this, as well as the time spent on these steps, was 1,521,100 USD.  Of this cost, 747,900 USD was cancelled through the November 2011/April 2012 Letters (captured in this project). 773,200 USD was still owed, and was drawn from an interest-free credit line provided through an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) signed March 21, 1994 (captured in project #88259).  The grant associated with what appears to be a feasibility study for the Center is captured in project #85568.
staff_comments: Project not coded as umbrella due to no risk of over counting; the specific amount forgiven is provided in sources, and the ETCA that likely otherwise would be charged would have been provided prior to 2000 and thus not in AidData's database.The feasibility study in #85568 for the Quito Center appears to be a different project, because it was specifically financed by separate Letters of Exchange signed in 2004, not by the February 2005 Letters assigned with the steps that were paid for in project (i.e. design creation).
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
Chinese government cancels 747,900 USD of debt accrued for now-cancelled Quito Education Center Project (linked to #85568 and #88259)

# Description
On February 1, 2005, the governments of Ecuador and China signed Letters of Exchange committing an unknown amount of funding to the Quito Education Center Project (Proyecto de Centro Educativo de Quito) (captured in project #98658).   However, in Letters of Exchange signed November 14, 2011 and April 13, 2012, at the request of the Government of Ecuador, the project was cancelled. At that point, the preliminary design and detailed project exploration had already taken place. The costs associated with this, as well as the time spent on these steps, was 1,521,100 USD.  Of this cost, 747,900 USD was cancelled through the November 2011/April 2012 Letters (captured in this project). 773,200 USD was still owed, and was drawn from an interest-free credit line provided through an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) signed March 21, 1994 (captured in project #88259).  The grant associated with what appears to be a feasibility study for the Center is captured in project #85568.
justification: Project involves debt cancellation for a cancelled education center, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Debt cancellation for education center project, no energy-related components mentioned

title: CDB provides $200 million loan to NBE for investment projects and SMEs (Linked to Project ID#30705 and ID#58774)
description: On August 28, 2012, during Egyptian President Mohammed Morsi's state visit to China, China Development Bank (CDB) and the National Bank of Egypt (NBE) — a commercial bank that is wholly owned by the Government of Egypt — signed a $200 million loan agreement to finance investment projects in Egypt as well as small and medium sized enterprises (SMEs) in Egypt. The loan was provided on the following terms: an 8-year maturity, a 3-year grace period, and an annual interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (0.718% in August 2012) plus a 3.75% margin. No information on loan disbursements could be identified.
staff_comments: 1. Hong Kong Government News and and one of two reporters from Voice of America identify the $200,000,000 as a credit line rather than a soft loan. Given the loan's maturity, interest rate, and grace period, AidData assumes that the agreement does in fact refer to a loan as opposed to a credit line. 2.  The loan's interest rate was calculated by finding the average USD LIBOR Overnight Rate for August 2012, .167%, and adding it to 3.75% as stipulated by the loan agreement, for a total interest rate of 3.971%.
combined_text:
# Sector
BUSINESS AND OTHER SERVICES

# Title
CDB provides $200 million loan to NBE for investment projects and SMEs (Linked to Project ID#30705 and ID#58774)

# Description
On August 28, 2012, during Egyptian President Mohammed Morsi's state visit to China, China Development Bank (CDB) and the National Bank of Egypt (NBE) — a commercial bank that is wholly owned by the Government of Egypt — signed a $200 million loan agreement to finance investment projects in Egypt as well as small and medium sized enterprises (SMEs) in Egypt. The loan was provided on the following terms: an 8-year maturity, a 3-year grace period, and an annual interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (0.718% in August 2012) plus a 3.75% margin. No information on loan disbursements could be identified.
justification: Loan agreement for general investment projects and SMEs without specific environmental or energy transition focus
evidence: General financing for investment projects and SMEs, no specific sector or environmental details provided

title: MOFCOM provides grant for Phase 2 of Egyptian Police Vehicles Project (Linked to Project ID#30426, ID#58577 and ID#30713)
description: On August 29, 2012, during Egyptian President Mohammed Morsi's state visit to China, China’s Ministry of Commerce provided a grant to the Government of Egypt for Phase 2 of the Egyptian Police Vehicles Project. The monetary value of this grant commitment is unknown. This project involved the supply of 300 police vehicles to the Egyptian Ministry of Interior. More specifically, it involved the provision of 150 Brilliance Jinbei Mini Buses and 150 Brilliance H530 sedans.   The ultimate purpose of the project was to restore a set of vehicles to the Egyptian police force following the significant property damage that took place after the January 25th Revolution. China's Brilliance auto-manufacturer was the contractor responsible for implementation. It is not clear whether or when this project was implemented. China’s Ministry of Commerce also provided a grant for Phase 1 of this project (captured in project ID#30705).
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 援埃车辆项目. The Arabic project title is  '300 سيارةلدعم جهاز الشرطة'
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
MOFCOM provides grant for Phase 2 of Egyptian Police Vehicles Project (Linked to Project ID#30426, ID#58577 and ID#30713)

# Description
On August 29, 2012, during Egyptian President Mohammed Morsi's state visit to China, China’s Ministry of Commerce provided a grant to the Government of Egypt for Phase 2 of the Egyptian Police Vehicles Project. The monetary value of this grant commitment is unknown. This project involved the supply of 300 police vehicles to the Egyptian Ministry of Interior. More specifically, it involved the provision of 150 Brilliance Jinbei Mini Buses and 150 Brilliance H530 sedans.   The ultimate purpose of the project was to restore a set of vehicles to the Egyptian police force following the significant property damage that took place after the January 25th Revolution. China's Brilliance auto-manufacturer was the contractor responsible for implementation. It is not clear whether or when this project was implemented. China’s Ministry of Commerce also provided a grant for Phase 1 of this project (captured in project ID#30705).
justification: Project involves supply of police vehicles for law enforcement purposes, with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Provision of 300 police vehicles (150 mini buses and 150 sedans) for Egyptian police force, no mention of energy or environmental aspects

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 32 million grant for Chinese Garden Project (Linked to Project ID#58589 and ID#72463)
description: On April 12, 2012, the Chinese Ambassador to Egypt, Song Aiguo, and the Egyptian Minister of Planning and International Cooperation, Fayza Abul-Naga, signed an exchange of letters, which committed RMB 32 million of grant funding for the Chinese Garden Project. These grant proceeds were drawn in part from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that was signed by the two governments on June 15, 2009 [see Egyptian Presidential Decision no. 383 (2009)]. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) is the source of funding for this project. The purpose of the project is to construct a Chinese style park (or ‘garden’) in Luxor City. Its ultimate aim is to lure tourists to Luxor City. On October 21, 2014, the Chinese Economic and Commercial Counselor to Egypt, Han Qing, and the Governor of Luxor, Maj. Gen. Tariq Saadeddin, discussed the park project's implementation. Then, on January 30, 2016, a delegation from the MOFCOM visited Luxor Governorate to discuss the project's location with the provincial government.  It was originally envisaged that the park would be located near Luxor general hospital to overlook the Nile River. However, as of mid-2016, alternative project locations were being considered. As of August 30, 2020, AidData could not identify any evidence that this project ever entered implementation.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 国卢克索省中国公园项目 or 阿拉伯埃及共和国卢克索省中国公园项目. The Arabic project title is حديقة ذات طبيعة صينية بمدينة الأقصر.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 32 million grant for Chinese Garden Project (Linked to Project ID#58589 and ID#72463)

# Description
On April 12, 2012, the Chinese Ambassador to Egypt, Song Aiguo, and the Egyptian Minister of Planning and International Cooperation, Fayza Abul-Naga, signed an exchange of letters, which committed RMB 32 million of grant funding for the Chinese Garden Project. These grant proceeds were drawn in part from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that was signed by the two governments on June 15, 2009 [see Egyptian Presidential Decision no. 383 (2009)]. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) is the source of funding for this project. The purpose of the project is to construct a Chinese style park (or ‘garden’) in Luxor City. Its ultimate aim is to lure tourists to Luxor City. On October 21, 2014, the Chinese Economic and Commercial Counselor to Egypt, Han Qing, and the Governor of Luxor, Maj. Gen. Tariq Saadeddin, discussed the park project's implementation. Then, on January 30, 2016, a delegation from the MOFCOM visited Luxor Governorate to discuss the project's location with the provincial government.  It was originally envisaged that the park would be located near Luxor general hospital to overlook the Nile River. However, as of mid-2016, alternative project locations were being considered. As of August 30, 2020, AidData could not identify any evidence that this project ever entered implementation.
justification: Project focuses on cultural development and tourism without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of Chinese style park in Luxor City aimed at attracting tourists, funded through social infrastructure grant

title: China Eximbank provides $56 million loan for Fiberglass Production Line Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#30924, ID#91748, and ID#91765)
description: In January 2012, China Jushi Co., Ltd (“China Jushi”), the world’s largest fiberglass manufacturer, created a special purpose vehicle and wholly-owned subsidiary called Jushi Egypt for Fiberglass Industry S.A.E (Jushi Egypt). China Development Bank and China Eximbank subsequently issued a $156 million loan and a $56 million loan, respectively, to Jushi Egypt for the construction of a 80,000-ton-a-year fiberglass production line (alkali-free glass fiber kiln drawing production line) located in Egypt’s Suez Economic and Trade Cooperation Zone.   CDB’s loan, which carried an 8 year maturity, is captured via Project ID#91765. China Eximbank’s loan, which carried an 8 year maturity, is captured via Project ID#91748. The first phase of the project cost $223 million and it was put into operation on April 23, 2014. The project’s second phase involved the construction of another 80,000 ton/year production line, It was put into operation in July 2016. The third phase of the project, which involved the construction of a 40,000 ton/year production line, was completed in June 2017.  Jushi Egypt has reportedly created 2,500 local jobs. Its products are mainly supplied to Europe, as well as Turkey, Middle East and North Africa, and Egyptian local markets.
staff_comments: 1. It is unknown if CDB or China Eximbank provided additional financing for the second and third phases of the project. This issue merits further investigation
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
China Eximbank provides $56 million loan for Fiberglass Production Line Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#30924, ID#91748, and ID#91765)

# Description
In January 2012, China Jushi Co., Ltd (“China Jushi”), the world’s largest fiberglass manufacturer, created a special purpose vehicle and wholly-owned subsidiary called Jushi Egypt for Fiberglass Industry S.A.E (Jushi Egypt). China Development Bank and China Eximbank subsequently issued a $156 million loan and a $56 million loan, respectively, to Jushi Egypt for the construction of a 80,000-ton-a-year fiberglass production line (alkali-free glass fiber kiln drawing production line) located in Egypt’s Suez Economic and Trade Cooperation Zone.   CDB’s loan, which carried an 8 year maturity, is captured via Project ID#91765. China Eximbank’s loan, which carried an 8 year maturity, is captured via Project ID#91748. The first phase of the project cost $223 million and it was put into operation on April 23, 2014. The project’s second phase involved the construction of another 80,000 ton/year production line, It was put into operation in July 2016. The third phase of the project, which involved the construction of a 40,000 ton/year production line, was completed in June 2017.  Jushi Egypt has reportedly created 2,500 local jobs. Its products are mainly supplied to Europe, as well as Turkey, Middle East and North Africa, and Egyptian local markets.
justification: Project focuses on fiberglass production, which does not have a clear environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Construction of fiberglass production lines, no mention of renewable energy or energy efficiency components
